hints_html:
The median m is defined as that number, which satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

A simple substitution may be helpful to evaluate the integral.
hints_latex: A simple substitution may be helpful to evaluate the integral.
hints_raw:
The median ''m'' is defined as that number, which satisfies

:<math>
\int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx = \frac12 = \int_m^\infty f(x)\,dx
</math>
A simple substitution may be helpful to evaluate the integral.
sols_html:
Probability was not covered this year, hence this is not material for the April 2012 exam.

Since f(x) = 0 for x\(\leq\) 0 it follows that m > 0. Now we can directly compute m:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^m 2xe^{-x^2}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

We use the substitution u = x2, du = 2x dx. Then u(0) = 0 and u(m) = m2. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\ &= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^m 2xe^{-x^2}\,dx \\ &= \int_0^{m^2} e^{-u}\,du \\ &= \left.-e^{-u}\right|_0^{m^2} \\ &= -e^{-m^2}+e^0 \\ &= 1-e^{-m^2}.\end{aligned}\]

In other words, m satisfies

\[\begin{aligned} \frac12 &= 1-e^{-m^2} \\ e^{-m^2} &= \frac12 \\ -m^2 &= \ln(2^{-1}) \\ m^2 &= \ln 2 \\ m &= \pm\sqrt{\ln 2}\end{aligned}\]

Note that we can rule out the solution \(m = -\sqrt{\ln 2}\) since we already noted that m is positive.

Hence, the solution is \(m=\sqrt{\ln 2}\).
sols_latex:
\emph{Probability was not covered this year, hence this is not material
for the April 2012 exam.}

Since \emph{f}(\emph{x}) = 0 for \emph{x}$\leq$ 0 it follows that
\emph{m} \textgreater{} 0. Now we can directly compute \emph{m}:

\begin{align*}
\frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^m 2xe^{-x^2}\,dx
\end{align*}

We use the substitution \emph{u} = \emph{x}\textsuperscript{2},
\emph{du} = 2\emph{x} \emph{dx}. Then \emph{u}(0) = 0 and
\emph{u}(\emph{m}) = \emph{m}\textsuperscript{2}. Hence

\begin{align*}
\frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^m 2xe^{-x^2}\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{m^2} e^{-u}\,du \\
&= \left.-e^{-u}\right|_0^{m^2} \\
&= -e^{-m^2}+e^0 \\
&= 1-e^{-m^2}.
\end{align*}

In other words, \emph{m} satisfies

\begin{align*}
\frac12 &= 1-e^{-m^2} \\
e^{-m^2} &= \frac12 \\
-m^2 &= \ln(2^{-1}) \\
m^2 &= \ln 2 \\
m &= \pm\sqrt{\ln 2}
\end{align*}

Note that we can rule out the solution $m = -\sqrt{\ln 2}$ since we
already noted that \emph{m} is positive.

Hence, the solution is $m=\sqrt{\ln 2}$.
sols_raw:
''Probability was not covered this year, hence this is not material for the April 2012 exam.''

Since ''f''(''x'') = 0 for ''x''&le; 0 it follows that ''m'' > 0. Now we can directly compute ''m'':

:<math>\begin{align}
\frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^m 2xe^{-x^2}\,dx
\end{align} </math>

We use the substitution ''u'' = ''x''<sup>2</sup>, ''du'' = 2''x'' ''dx''. Then ''u''(0) = 0 and ''u''(''m'') = ''m''<sup>2</sup>. Hence

:<math> \begin{align}
\frac12 &= \int_{-\infty}^m f(x)\,dx \\
&= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^m 2xe^{-x^2}\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{m^2} e^{-u}\,du \\
&= \left.-e^{-u}\right|_0^{m^2} \\
&= -e^{-m^2}+e^0 \\
&= 1-e^{-m^2}.
\end{align} </math>

In other words, ''m'' satisfies
:<math> \begin{align}
\frac12 &= 1-e^{-m^2} \\
e^{-m^2} &= \frac12 \\
-m^2 &= \ln(2^{-1}) \\
m^2 &= \ln 2 \\
m &= \pm\sqrt{\ln 2}
\end{align} </math>

Note that we can rule out the solution <math> m = -\sqrt{\ln 2} </math> since we already noted that ''m'' is positive.

Hence, the solution is <math> m=\sqrt{\ln 2}</math>.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required.

X is a random variable with probability density function \(f(x) = 2xe^{-x^{2}}\) where \(x \geq 0\). Find the median of X.
statement_latex:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

\emph{X} is a random variable with probability density function
$f(x) = 2xe^{-x^{2}}$ where $x \geq 0$. Find the median of \emph{X}.
statement_raw:
<b> Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required. </b>

''X'' is a random variable with probability density function <math> f(x) = 2xe^{-x^{2}} </math> where <math> x \geq 0 </math>. Find the median of ''X''.
